items.title: paramiko/2.7.1: tests/configs/ directory is missing, leading to test failures
items.body:
Hello,
while updating paramiko/2.7.1 for debian, we discovered that `tests/configs/` directory is not included in the tarball released to PyPI, this leads to test failures when running the testsuite:

```

tests/test_config.py:54: 
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _

    @classmethod

        """
        Create a new, parsed `SSHConfig` from the file found at ``path``.
    
        .. versionadded:: 2.7
        """
>       with open(path) as flo:

paramiko/config.py:108: FileNotFoundError
...etc...
```

can you please include that directory in the next release so that we can tests run without failure? thanks!

items.title: python3.7 + paramiko2.71 + pyinstaller：Error reading SSH protocol banner
items.body:
I run my code in pycharm as follows:
`import paramiko

ssh=paramiko.Transport(('192.168.0.128',22))

ssh.connect(username='xx',password='xx')

sftp=paramiko.SFTPClient.from_transport(ssh)

#Copy a local file (localpath) to the SFTP server as remotepath
sftp.put('user.ini','/data/wj/123/1.ini')

ssh.close()`
It execute successfully and the file "user.ini" indeed is uploaded from client to sever. But when the code is built to ".exe" by pyinstaller, it report a error:`Exception: Error reading SSH protocol banner
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "site-packages\paramiko\transport.py", line 2211, in _check_banner
  File "site-packages\paramiko\packet.py", line 380, in readline
  File "site-packages\paramiko\packet.py", line 609, in _read_timeout
EOFError

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "site-packages\paramiko\transport.py", line 2039, in run
  File "site-packages\paramiko\transport.py", line 2216, in _check_banner
paramiko.ssh_exception.SSHException: Error reading SSH protocol banner`

I tried the method : modifying banner_timeout = 300 but it is useless. Can you give me some advices?

items.title: How can I implement "direct-tcpip" on a Paramiko server?
items.body:
Looking at the documentation, I couldn't find any useful pointers on how to implement "direct-tcpip" (aka `ssh ... -L local_port:remote_host:remote_port`) on a SSH server written in Paramiko.

The only thing that I know after reading the documentation is that I can do this:

```
class Server(paramiko.ServerInterface):
    # ...
    def check_channel_direct_tcpip_request(self, chanid, origin, destination):
        return paramiko.OPEN_SUCCEEDED
```

However, when I try to connect to the local port, I get no response back, presumably because I need to supply my own implementation that handles the communication.

Is there a simple example on how I can send or receive data from a direct-tcpip request?

items.title: Setting Transport.connect auth_timeout
items.body:
Hi,

I see [auth_timeout defaults to 30 at init](https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko/blob/ae3d0febef17a8ece5268bbf6c210a30573ce800/paramiko/transport.py#L489). How would I set that during a call to transport.connect? Something like this...

```
transport = paramiko.Transport((hostname, port)
transport.auth_timeout = 60
transport.connect(self=transport, username=username, password=password, pkey=pkey)
```

items.title: Could not deserialize key data
items.body:
Paramiko 2.7.1 crashes when importing a PEM key that contains leading whitespace. Version 2.5.1 does not have this problem.

Example:
```

import paramiko

key = """
-----BEGIN RSA PRIVATE KEY-----

"""

paramiko.RSAKey.from_private_key(io.StringIO(key))  # paramiko.ssh_exception.SSHException: Could not deserialize key data.
paramiko.RSAKey.from_private_key(io.StringIO(key.lstrip()))  # works after stripping leading whitespace
```

paramiko.pkey.PKey._read_private_key does appear to correctly detect the start of the key but this info is not passed on to paramiko.pkey.PKey._read_private_key_pem which then ends up including the leading whitespace in the key data.

items.title: Cannot listdir if any sub-directory inside dir is unreadable
items.body:
listdir uses listdir_attr internally.  listdir_attr uses,

>self._request(CMD_OPENDIR, path)

Thus if any sub-directory is unreadable, there is no method by which to get a directory listing of the level above that at all.

1) I scanned the key from a remote host, saved it to a known_hosts file but connecting to this remote host failed because of no key in the known_hosts file.
2) changing/adding the orginal entry of the known_hosts file -> connection was successful

see example:
----
import paramiko

host = 'sv207.zt.ic.ank.com'
port = 30000
knownhostsfile = '/opt/known_hosts'

transport = paramiko.Transport((host, port))
transport.connect()
key = transport.get_remote_server_key()
transport.close()

hostfile = paramiko.hostkeys.HostKeys(filename=knownhostsfile)
hostfile.add(hostname = host, key=key, keytype=key.get_name())

...

Unable to establish SSH connection: <class 'paramiko.ssh_exception.SSHException'> ("Server '[sv207.zt.ic.ank.com]:30000' not found in known_hosts",)

items.body:
I use paramiko for uploading and downloading files over SFTP however today I found out it always connects using the default port 22 instead of a given custom port.
I verified by manually connecting to the server using the paramiko sftp client and doing a listdir() and found that it is connecting to the default port 22 everytime.
Here are the commands I used 
```
import paramiko
transport = paramiko.Transport('IP', port)
transport.connect(username='user', password='pass')

sftp.listdir()
transport.close()
```
Please me resolve this issue. It is breaking a lot of things since we often do not use the default port for sftp.

items.title: Inconsistent output length with get_pty()
items.body:
Was wondering if somebody could shed some light on the below behavior.

I rely on back and forth communication with the remote server, hence I use `get_pty()` (default width of 80 characters) and `invoke_shell()`. I then run two different 'ps' commands with different arguments on the server which should return some processes that I am interested in. What I noted is that with one of the two commands, the pty width of 80 characters is enforced, and with the other one this is not the case. See below code to demonstrate this behavior

```
import paramiko
import socket

def receive_output(some_channel):
    data = b''
    while True:
        if some_channel.recv_ready():
            data += some_channel.recv(1024)

        if data.endswith(b'~]$ '):
            return data.decode()


sock = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
sock.connect(('192.168.1.100', 22))
transport = paramiko.Transport(sock)
transport.start_client()
transport.auth_password('username', 'password')
channel = transport.open_channel('session')
channel.get_pty()
channel.invoke_shell()

channel.sendall('ps -ef|grep gluster_volmgr|grep -v grep\n')
output_1 = receive_output(channel)
print('output 1:')
for line in output_1.splitlines():
    print(line)


print(2 * '\n')
print(50 * '-')


channel.sendall('ps -fp $(pgrep gluster_volmgr)\n')
output_2 = receive_output(channel)
print('output 2:')
for line in output_2.splitlines():
    print(line)

channel.close()
transport.close()
```

And the output:

```
output 1:
Last login: Wed Jan  8 08:57:47 2020 from 192.168.222.98

rootA
ps -ef|grep gluster_volmgr|grep -v grep
[username@LRTBPP1 ~]$ ps -ef|grep gluster_volmgr|grep -v grep
root     23853 23623  0  2019 ?        00:01:41 gluster_volmgr -pid 10000 -pn gluster_volmgr -ipc ilrm_0_IPC -adm eth0.1 -cluster_id 123225 -cp 10000 -mode pp_mnc -nms_obj_id 123228 -pp_id 128 -rid idirect_gluster_volume_mgr -sid 11 -tun eth0.4048 
[username@LRTBPP1 ~]$ 



--------------------------------------------------
output 2:
ps -fp $(pgrep gluster_volmgr)
UID        PID  PPID  C STIME TTY          TIME CMD
root     23853 23623  0  2019 ?        00:01:41 gluster_volmgr -pid 10000 -pn gl
[username@LRTBPP1 ~]$ 

Process finished with exit code 0
```

As per above, the output of the first command matches the full line, however the output of the second command is cut of at exactly 80 characters. This is consistently happening, and the order in which these commands are executed has no effect, it is always `ps -p $(pgrep gluster_volmgr)` where the output is cut off at 80 characters. Note that this is also the case when I hard code the PID (e.g. `ps -fp 23853`.

This is not a major issue, as there are easy workarounds, but I was wondering what the cause might be. 

On a different note, I also noted that the first command that is sent after `invoke_shell()` is always printed present twice the output, as per above. Is the command actually sent to the server twice?

items.title: Unexpected exception from paramiko.RSAKey.from_private_key
items.body:
According to the docs https://docs.paramiko.org/en/2.7/api/keys.html#paramiko.pkey.PKey.from_private_key_file, reading an invalid keyfile should raise an SSHException, but instead it seems to raise an AttributeError.

Tested on python3.8, Windows 10-Pro 64-bit, paramiko version 2.7.0

Example:
```
import paramiko
open('badkey', 'x').close()
paramiko.RSAKey.from_private_key('badkey')

```

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "p.py", line 3, in <module>
    paramiko.RSAKey.from_private_key('badkey')
  File "C:\Program Files\Python38\lib\site-packages\paramiko\pkey.py", line 244, in from_private_key
    key = cls(file_obj=file_obj, password=password)
  File "C:\Program Files\Python38\lib\site-packages\paramiko\rsakey.py", line 52, in __init__
    self._from_private_key(file_obj, password)
  File "C:\Program Files\Python38\lib\site-packages\paramiko\rsakey.py", line 179, in _from_private_key
    data = self._read_private_key("RSA", file_obj, password)
  File "C:\Program Files\Python38\lib\site-packages\paramiko\pkey.py", line 300, in _read_private_key
    lines = f.readlines()
AttributeError: 'str' object has no attribute 'readlines'

```

items.title: OSError: Operation unsupported when using posix_rename on folder (Ubuntu 18.04)
items.body:
Hello,

I want to recursively rename my folder structure with a python script from
```/ftp-server/folder_name1/file_name1.ext```
to
```/ftp-server/folder_name2/file_name2.ext```
where `name1` is some identifier that must be changed to `name2`. For files this works without problems, but the following code fails on my system:

``` python
import paramiko
ssh_client = paramiko.SSHClient()
ssh_client.set_missing_host_key_policy(paramiko.AutoAddPolicy())
ssh_client.connect("some.server," username="some_user", key_filename="keyfile.pem")

# this line fails:
sftp_client.posix_rename("/ftp-server/folder_name1/", "/ftp-server/folder_name2/")
# this works:
sftp_client.posix_rename("/ftp-server/folder_name1/file_name1.ext", "/ftp-server/folder_name1/file_name2.ext")
```

The error is: `*** OSError: Operation unsupported`

Any idea? Workaround would be to create the target directory (`test_folder2`) copy the directory content from the source directory (`test_folder1`) and delete it afterwards. Copying means down- and uploading which is very inefficient.

Edit: OS: Linux Mint 19.1 (Ubuntu 18.04 based), python 3.6.8

items.title: ECDSA keys parsing fails due to key format changes
items.body:
Paramiko expect:
`-----BEGIN EC PRIVATE KEY-------`
while on SLES 15 and Ubuntu 19.04  key is generated with header:
`-----BEGIN OPENSSH PRIVATE KEY-----`

As result, key parsing failed with: `paramiko.ssh_exception.SSHException: not a valid EC private key file`

Example key (passwordless, made by calling `ssh-keygen -t ecdsa -b 521 -C test -f ~/ssh_key_test`):
```

items.title: Allow non-monkeypatch mutation of preferred kex algorithms etc
items.body:
There may well be an open feature ticket or PR for this but I can't find it...:unamused:

Most recent example of why this is frequently useful: #1455, where the recently released new set of kex algorithms doesn't work in all cases and users need to disable it without just downgrading back to the previous release. But it comes up basically anytime we modify the set of implemented kexen, ciphers, etc.

It'd be nice if this could play well with OpenSSH config support as well, but last I checked we don't actually do a lot of automagic handling there so that might need to live in Fabric 2 land. I'd also rather get this out sooner instead of later.

items.title: SSHException should define _str_ method
items.body:
Most `paramiko.ssh_exception.SSHException` subclasses call `SSHException.__init__(self, message)` with some nicely crafted message.
However, since they overwrite `self.args = (...)` just a few lines later, the `Exception.args` used in `Exception.__str__` don't return the `message` but basically `str(self.args)`.

```python
class BadHostKeyException(SSHException):
    def __init__(self, hostname, got_key, expected_key):
        message = (
            "Host key for server {} does not match: got {}, expected {}"
        )  # noqa
        message = message.format(
            hostname, got_key.get_base64(), expected_key.get_base64()
        )
        SSHException.__init__(self, message)
        self.hostname = hostname
        self.key = got_key
        self.expected_key = expected_key
        # for unpickling
        self.args = (hostname, got_key, expected_key)
```

For example:

```python
In [1]: from paramiko.ssh_exception import BadHostKeyException                                                                                                            

In [2]: from paramiko.ed25519key import Ed25519Key                                                                                                                        

# Assume this key exists
In [3]: key = Ed25519Key.from_private_key_file('ssh_host_ed25519_key')                                                                            

In [4]: exc = BadHostKeyException('somehost', key, key)                                                                                                                   

In [5]: exc.args                                                                                                                                                          
Out[5]: 
('somehost',
 <paramiko.ed25519key.Ed25519Key at 0x7f6dcc122b00>,
 <paramiko.ed25519key.Ed25519Key at 0x7f6dcc122b00>)

In [6]: str(exc)                                                                                                                                                          
Out[6]: "('somehost', <paramiko.ed25519key.Ed25519Key object at 0x7f6dcc122b00>, <paramiko.ed25519key.Ed25519Key object at 0x7f6dcc122b00>)"
```

items.title: [Feature Request] Provide a method for getting a remote's sshd version
items.body:
This is actually fairly easy to do (and can be done with a raw socket), it'd just be great if it was exposed in paramiko.

Quick POC:
```Python3
import socket

try:
    sock = socket.socket()
    sock.settimeout(10)
    sock.connect(('cylon', 22))
    version = sock.recv(64).decode('utf-8').strip()
    # version is a string like "SSH-2.0-OpenSSH_7.9"
    sock.close()
except Exception as e:
    # Obviously you can specify multiple exceptions to catch.
    raise RuntimeError(e)
```

items.title: Raises 'Invalid key' on valid OPENSSH private key
items.body:
Context: 
- no passphrase.
- keyfile works flawlessly with `ssh -i ...`
- Paramiko throws `Invalid key` during the public key checking phase when using a file containing the private key. 

https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko/blob/cf7d49d66f3b1fbc8b0853518a54050182b3b5eb/paramiko/ed25519key.py#L130

keyfile is 2048 bit RSA:
 
```
$ ssh-keygen -l -f ~/.ssh/the_key.pem 
2048 SHA256:VfQdzkeQp31B2XgUEAhznNfJ5Wxt8x9KiD8PGsd3uSQ foo (RSA)
```

file starts with:

```
-----BEGIN OPENSSH PRIVATE KEY-----
```

Both `class RSAKey(PKey)` and `class Ed25519Key(PKey)` fail to support this valid key file format.

I want my script to 1) login to a Cisco switch and do a "show inventory" command (done successfully so far) 2) save the output of "SN: FOCxxxxxxxx" _**in memory**_ instead of saving it to a local file.

I want to do this in order to be able to match each serial number to a particular IP address.

Any ideas what I can do to achieve this?

Thanks!
Tiam

Feature offer: SSH port tunneling/forwarding/reversing/SOCKS
items.body:
Is there any issue with me implementing local (`ssh -L`), remote (`ssh -R`) and dynamic tunnels (`ssh -D`) and providing it under the `paramiko.client.SSHClient` class?


I know these are in the demos and this has a merge to fabric (that is still not accepted into fabric) but I think that as part of an SSH client would make sense as I had come across this and would like to have this feature as this is pretty standard.

I'd like this as I wish to bring the feature into a library I am writing to replace `pxssh` in pexpect.

I am willing to write this, I just don't want to write it then have it sit in the merge queue for years and years to come or get outright denied after doing the work.

items.title: Trouble authenticating through SSH relay using double authentication
items.body:
Hello all,

I'm having trouble authenticating with paramiko using a proxy relay. Here is the setup: I'm trying to connect to a distant server with SFTP. I' can't connect directly to it, but I have to use a SSH/SFTP relay: the command line is something like `sftp proxyuser@distantuser@distant-server.com@relay-proxy-address.com`. It works fine with the command line, requesting first the relay password, then the distant server's password, then giving me the SFTP prompt. I added the full log of a successful SFTP connexion (with -vvv option) as attachment: [log_sftp.txt](https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko/files/2879625/log_sftp.txt)

However, I am unable to make it work using paramiko.

Here is the closest code I got from an effective connexion:
```python
def openConnexionWithProxy(self, serverUrl_, user_, userPass_, proxyUrl_, proxyUser_, proxyPass_):
        """
        """
        # Reset SFTP Client
        self._sftpClient = None
        
        # More logs
        paramiko.common.logging.basicConfig(level=paramiko.common.DEBUG)
        
        # Handler for password questions
        def answer_handler(title, instructions, prompt_list):
            print "answer_handler call with title: '{0}', instructions: '{1}', \
                prompt_list: '{2}'".format(title, instructions, prompt_list)
            
            if prompt_list[0][0] == 'Gateway password: ':
                print "handler answer: gateway password request"
                passrequested = proxyPass_
            else:
                print "handler answer: final password request"
                passrequested = userPass_
            
            return passrequested + "\n"
        
        # Construction of proxy-required username
        usernameWithProxy = "{0}@{1}@{2}".format(proxyUser_, user_, serverUrl_)
        
        print "Transport object creation and connexion"
        transport = paramiko.Transport((proxyUrl_, 22))
        transport.use_compression()
        transport.connect()
        
        try:
            # For some reason, this is necessary, otherwise the answer handler 
            # of auth_interactive is never called and an "Authentication failed" exception is raised directly
            print "trying auth_none"
            transport.auth_none(usernameWithProxy)
            # It fails, so we never get to see the following
            print "succeeded???!?" 
        except paramiko.ssh_exception.BadAuthenticationType as e:
            pass
        
        print "auth interactive"
        transport.auth_interactive(usernameWithProxy, answer_handler)
        print "auth_interactive end"
        
        self._sftpClient = paramiko.SFTPClient.from_transport(transport)
        print "SFTP client opened"
        
        # Returning established connexion
        return self._sftpClient
```

The problem I have is that `auth_interactive` raises an `Authentication failed` exception. Here is the debug output:
```
Transport object creation and connexion
DEBUG:paramiko.transport:starting thread (client mode): 0x5d86ca90L
DEBUG:paramiko.transport:Local version/idstring: SSH-2.0-paramiko_2.4.2
DEBUG:paramiko.transport:Banner: Greeting
DEBUG:paramiko.transport:Remote version/idstring: SSH-2.0-SSH
INFO:paramiko.transport:Connected (version 2.0, client SSH)
DEBUG:paramiko.transport:kex algos:[u'diffie-hellman-group-exchange-sha256', u'diffie-hellman-group-exchange-sha1', u'diffie-hellman-group14-sha1'] server key:[u'ssh-rsa'] client encrypt:[u'aes128-ctr', u'aes192-ctr', u'aes256-ctr'] server encrypt:[u'aes128-ctr', u'aes192-ctr', u'aes256-ctr'] client mac:[u'hmac-sha2-256', u'hmac-sha2-512'] server mac:[u'hmac-sha2-256', u'hmac-sha2-512'] client compress:[u'none'] server compress:[u'none'] client lang:[u''] server lang:[u''] kex follows?False
DEBUG:paramiko.transport:Kex agreed: diffie-hellman-group-exchange-sha256
DEBUG:paramiko.transport:HostKey agreed: ssh-rsa
DEBUG:paramiko.transport:Cipher agreed: aes128-ctr
DEBUG:paramiko.transport:MAC agreed: hmac-sha2-256
DEBUG:paramiko.transport:Compression agreed: none
DEBUG:paramiko.transport:Got server p (2048 bits)
DEBUG:paramiko.transport:kex engine KexGexSHA256 specified hash_algo <built-in function openssl_sha256>
DEBUG:paramiko.transport:Switch to new keys ...
trying auth_none
debut wait_for_response
DEBUG:paramiko.transport:userauth is OK
INFO:paramiko.transport:Auth banner: This is the first message of the proxy
DEBUG:paramiko.transport:Authentication type (none) not permitted.
DEBUG:paramiko.transport:Allowed methods: [u'keyboard-interactive']
auth interactive
DEBUG:paramiko.transport:userauth is OK
answer_handler call with title: 'Gateway authentication and authorization', instructions: 'Please specify the requested information', prompt_list: '[(u'Gateway password: ', False)]'
handler answer: gateway password request
DEBUG:paramiko.transport:EOF in transport thread
Exception   : Authentication failed.
Traceback   : [('./tecmcp_tins/tecmcp_sftplib.py', 1, 'openConnexionWithProxy', 'transport.auth_interactive(usernameWithProxy, answer_handler)'), ('/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/paramiko/transport.py', 1560, 'auth_interactive', 'return self.auth_handler.wait_for_response(my_event)'), ('/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/paramiko/auth_handler.py', 241, 'wait_for_response', 'raise e')]
```

Could anyone direct me to what I'm doing wrong here?

Many thanks,

SF

items.title: OpenSSH RSA problem
items.body:
Hey! I have been searching and searching for a answer.
Have taken me two days without a solution.

I recently moved from Linux Mint to Manjaro. And when I have generated RSA keys, Paramiko is telling me `not a valid RSA private key file`.
And inside the key so the first line is `BEGIN OPENSSH PRIVATE KEY`.
And it doesn't like that. I've asked a few peoples on what their line says. And they get `BEGIN RSA PRIVATE KEY`.

I've tried different ways of `ssh-keygen -b 4096 -t rsa` to try getting the same key as those on Linux Mint.
This problem occurs only with Paramiko and the keys are valid.
Running `ssh-keygen -l -f ~/.ssh/id_rsa` so the first part is `4096 SHA256`

I have also tried using [ed25519](http://docs.paramiko.org/en/2.4/api/keys.html#module-paramiko.ed25519key) from the documentation. But I didn't get that part to work either by using `ssh-keygen -t ed25519`.

I accidently posted on the wrong page but [these guys](https://github.com/iterative/dvc/issues/1187) also wants an answer to this problem!

Any suggestions what to do and how to do it is appreciated!

items.title: Receiving ^[[6n during recv with invoke_shell, then recv_ready() is False for 5 minutes
items.body:
When using invoke_shell(), even before sending on the channel, I expect to be able to recv(65535) at least up to the end of the login banner and prompt. Using Paramiko on Zyxel OLT2406.

At least, I am able to observe this behaviour on older firmware. However, on newer firmware (V4.02(AAVA.4)C0) I receive the copyright notice, but before the hostname arrives in the receive buffer, "^[[6n" appears, and and then no more characters. At this point recv_ready() is False. After waiting EXACTLY 300 seconds, recv_ready() becomes True, and the remainder of the login prompt (the hostname) can be read.

When manually SSH'ing to the device, (ie not using paramiko, just native ssh client) all is fine, and there is no delay before seeing the hostname in the prompt.

items.body:
This took a little digging.  I was being dumb, and put entirely the wrong username in for the tool to use, on an instance where I provided an SSH Key for authentication.   Paramiko incorrectly complained that I'd passed in an encrypted private key file, which I hadn't.  So far as I could gather by stepping through the code using pdb, It had been able to decrypt the key, it just couldn't use it to authenticate with.

Easy to replicate:
```
#!/usr/bin/env python

import paramiko

ip = some_ip_address

client = paramiko.SSHClient()
client.load_system_host_keys()
client.connect(ip, username="bad_username", key_filename="/path/to/ssh/key")
client.exec_command("ls -l /")
```

```

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "quick.py", line 11, in <module>

A straight authentication failure would probably have got me revisiting stuff, but saying "Private key file is encrypted" meant I went down totally the wrong investigative path!

items.title: Loading an Ed25519Key with a comment of certain lengths results in "Invalid key".
"Invalid key" error when an Ed25519Key is used with an incorrect passphrase
items.body:
When I call either of the following ...

    paramiko.ed25519key.Ed25519Key.from_private_key_file
    paramiko.SSHClient.connect

... with an incorrect key decryption passphrase, I get the following error:

    paramiko.ssh_exception.SSHException: Invalid key

Instead of the above error, I would expect an error telling me that the passphrase failed to decrypt the key.  I would recommend that the error message also include the path of the file that contained the key.

The "Invalid key" error can be very misleading.  For example, consider the following scenario with two key files:

    /tmp/key_ed25519     # this key is encrypted with passphrase "foo"
    ~/.ssh/id_ed25519    # this key has some other passphrase

Now consider the following series of events:

1 ) You call the following:

    paramiko.SSHClient.connect (
      key_filename='/tmp/key_ed25519'
      passphrase='foo' )    # other parameters omitted for purposes of illustration

2 ) paramiko will successfully decrypt the key and use it to attempt to connect to the remote host.

3 ) Let's say the key is not in `~/.ssh/authorized_keys` on the remote host.  So, the attempt to connect with the key will fail.

4 ) At this point, I would expect to receive an authentication failed exception.  However, no such exception is raised.  Instead...

5 ) paramiko will continue, and will now look for a key in `~/.ssh/id_ed25519`.  paramiko will attempt to decrypt this key, again using `passphrase='foo'`.  This key decryption will fail, and (confusingly) raise an `Invalid key` exception.  (There is nothing invalid about either key.  Paramiko is simply silently trying to use passphrase on a mismatched key file.)

Aside:  It seems entirely reasonable to me that different key files would be encrypted with different passphrases.  Yet paramiko is not designed to accommodate this configuration.  Paramiko will attempt to decrypt different key files with the same passphrase.  Error messages do not describe which key file caused any errors that occur.  So the error message is doubly confusing.  If it were my choice, I would either redesign paramiko so that passphrases are specified on a per key file basis, or so that if a key is explicitly provided the paramiko does not look for additional keys in `~/.ssh` .

Here is code to reproduce the bug:

    import  os
    import  paramiko

    os.system ( 'rm -f /tmp/key_ed25519' )
    os.system (
      'ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -N foo -f /tmp/key_ed25519 > /dev/null' )

    hostname      =  'localhost'
    username      =  'nobody'
    key_filename  =  '/tmp/key_ed25519'

    passphrase    =  'bar'
    #  passphrase   =  'foo'    # uncomment to search for keys in ~/.ssh        

    client  =  paramiko .SSHClient()
    client .set_missing_host_key_policy ( paramiko .AutoAddPolicy() )

    client .connect ( hostname=hostname,  username=username,
                      key_filename=key_filename, passphrase=passphrase )

items.title: Match Confusing Paramiko SSH Config Parsing?
items.body:
I was attempting to use `sshtunnel`, which has `paramiko` as a dependency, and hit an issue where the SSH configuration file parsing was picking up the wrong username. I can work around it, but it *seems* like a Paramiko defect to me.

Here's the related issue on `sshtunnel`:
https://github.com/pahaz/sshtunnel/issues/133

Essentially, given this configuration file:
```
Match Host 10.0.*.* User ec2-user
  User ec2-user
  IdentityFile ~/path/to/keys/key.pem
Host *
  UseKeychain yes
  AddKeysToAgent yes
  IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_rsa
VisualHostKey yes
```

Paramiko seems to decide that for host `dev`, the username should be `ec2-user`, which it shouldn't be:

```
Python 3.6.5 (default, Jun 24 2018, 13:09:28)
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 9.1.0 (clang-902.0.39.2)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from paramiko.config import SSHConfig
>>> config = SSHConfig()
>>> cfg_file='./ssh-cfg-simple'
>>> with open(cfg_file) as f:
...     config.parse(f)
...
>>> config.lookup('dev')
{'match': 'Host 10.0.*.* User ec2-user', 'user': 'ec2-user', 'identityfile': ['/path/to/key.pem', '/path/to/ssh/key'], 'usekeychain': 'yes', 'addkeystoagent': 'yes', 'visualhostkey': 'yes', 'hostname': 'dev'}
>>>
```

I cannot swear with certainty that there's nothing wrong with my configuration file (since I haven't found a canonical ssh configuration linter/parser), but I can assert that it works fine for me with ssh, just not with Paramiko.

items.title: Backport a version-agnostic form of crypto 1.5 compatibility
items.body:
Increasingly vexed by the enormous reams of warnings spat out by Paramiko <2.3 during test runs, caused by a lack of #979.

However, it's not nice to backport that ticket itself (because then dependencies will change in tertiary releases - I'm more flexible these days but that's beyond the pale) so I want to see if it's feasible to rewrite it for 2.0+ in a "if X else Y" fashion.

Ought to be straightforward? Famous last words...

Remember to make sure that the merge from 2.2 to 2.3 uses `-s ours` or similar, so that 2.3+ goes back to assuming what it's able.

items.title: Backport blackening, pytest to 2.0
items.body:
Been frustrated with the difficulty (or the perceived difficulty, hasn't happened a lot here specifically but was a huge problem for a while in Fabric, Invoke) of forward-porting changes through the 2.4.x era pytest and black overhauls. Trying to backport those to 2.0 onwards so we have a nice clean break at 2.0 (this is in part to support dropping 1.x support entirely, which has its own additional barrier to easy maintainership).

Specifically this means taking work for, or around, #1100 and an un-ticketed set of PyCon 2018 sprint changes around implementing `black` support, and cherry picking them back to 2.0. I am _hoping_ this goes as smoothly as such a thing can and that I am mostly going to be removing feature-related test blocks for stuff added in 2.1-2.4 (eg Ed25519 support).

Mostly making this a ticket to help track stuff I needed to tweak or defer.

items.title: [CVE-2018-1000805] Server-side auth vulnerability
items.body:
## Background

Security vulnerability on Paramiko's server side (**NOT** client side), as reported by Daniel Hoffman of [usd AG](https://www.usd.de/en/).

I was emailed by the above on 2018.08.31 and (due to being on vacation at the time) was able to review the initial information on today's date (2018.09.06). Daniel submitted the following:

- sample vanilla-enough server-side code loop (using standard/public API members with no additions besides logging and specification of expected auth mechanisms)
- sample client-side code which exploits the vulnerability in the server (TK)
- detailed explanation of why the exploit works, with references to parts of Paramiko's server-side code
- recommended fix

At time of writing, I have done a cursory read of the code snippets & explanation, and confirmed that the sample code does appear to exhibit the described exploit.

## Actual, post-fix description

The crux of it is as follows:

- The exploit is that malicious clients can trick the Paramiko server into thinking the client is authenticated, without providing any authentication. Yup. That's bad. Real bad.
- The flaw is in the `Transport` class, which is (regrettably IMHO; it's not my design) used unadulterated for both client and server use cases. No subclassing or anything; only a few very minor branch points.
- It, and its symbiont class `AuthHandler`, both maintain a few "handler tables" for dispatching on message types within the main event loop; e.g. see `MSG_USERAUTH_REQUEST`, dispatch to an auth request handler method.
- Smart users will already have put the previous facts together to figure out that...the exploit is the client sending `MSG_USERAUTH_SUCCESS` to the server. This is normally a server-to-client only message!
  - The Paramiko server then handles this message using a handler (within `AuthHandler`) _intended_ for use by _client use cases_, because there is no differentiation in play.
  - And because the code is so strongly shared, this ends up flipping a flag saying "the other end is authenticated", which the server code continues to reference to determine if the client passed auth.
- Thus, a malicious client can simply send that bogus message to set itself as authenticated for the rest of the session. Open, sesame.
- The fix has been to separate the handler tables into specific client vs server components (given that, at least for the AuthHandler where this all takes place, there are no bidirectionally useful message types) and serve up only one or the other during dispatch, never both.
  - This was done in a backwards compatible manner, replacing static dicts with a dict-returning `@property`.
- Due to expediency, I have not yet expanded this fix to the other couple of tables involved, but my guess is that the AuthHandler's table was the one that needed it most; past the auth step, any incorrect messages should just result in errors from the server and not exploitable server state.
- The fix has been backported to Paramiko 2.0 and up.

## TODO

- [x] take up Daniel on his offer to create a CVE; less work for me, but also, a security company has more experience with that process than I do, namely "any at all"
- [x] double check the details of the vulnerability so that I understand it more deeply
- [x] consider whether the suggested fix is valid (it has to do with Paramiko's reuse of code across client/server use cases)
- [ ] ~confirm exploit & fix are both valid to 1.17.x/1.18.x (at present I am still considering 1.17.x to be pseudo-LTS and getting bugfixes, though this will soon cease) and up~ _- nope, 2.0 and up, sorry folks. it's gotta happen sometime_
- [x] test, patch, confirm
- [x] changelog entry
  - **NOTE:** may want to wait for CVE filing if not done yet, so at least this one commit has the CVE number in it? also consider a rebase to add it to the main patch commit/s
- [x] merge up to all branches
- [x] push & release at once so fix is live
- [x] update this ticket with my notes/real description
- [x] send a security notice out via Tidelift as well as Twitter

items.title: please update interactive.py example to not use "hardcoded" u(chan.recv(1024))
items.body: as discussed (I think) in https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko/issues/302#issuecomment-290192663 it is not "proper" to read prespecified number of bytes (1024).  In our case e.g. it just leads to a crash since the 1024th byte is the first byte of the unicode character so decode blows.

items.title: How to not print ssh banner
items.body:
def connect(HOST, command):
    client = paramiko.SSHClient()
    client.set_missing_host_key_policy(paramiko.AutoAddPolicy())
    client.connect(hostname=HOST, username= USERNAME, password = PASSWORD)
    myshell = client.invoke_shell()
    myshell.send(command + '\n')
    time.sleep(2)
    output = myshell.recv(65535)
    print(output.decode(encoding='UTF-8'))

when i execute this script, it also print the banner..
how to not print this banner?
